column1: The Battle of Dale and the subsequent Siege of Erebor were decisive battles in the northern theatre of the War of the Ring. Even though it cost the lives of Kings Dáin Ironfoot and Brand
column2: it was a decisive victory for the Free peoples.

column1: The Dwarves of Erebor and the Men of Dale refused to acknowledge the overlordship and alliance of Sauron. While his southern armies menaced Gondor
column2: the Dark Lord sent an army north to extend his dominion to prevent the armies of his enemies joining together under one banner
column3: which could have proved disastrous for Mordor.

column1: File:Steamey - King Brand and King Dáin Ironfoot.jpgOn 17 March
column2: Sauron sent a large contingent of Easterlings to attack Dale. The combined forces of the Men of Dale under King Brand and the Dwarves of the Lonely Mountain under King Dáin Ironfoot marched out to meet the Easterlings in battle. After three days of heavy close-quarters fighting
column3: they were forced to retreat towards the Lonely Mountain.

column1: The armies fought bravely before the Gate of Erebor
column2: which was not taken. In the end
column3: Dáin was killed as he stood defending the body of his ally Brand. Meanwhile
column4: the defenders of the Mountain were able to withstand the siege.

column2: the forces of Gondor and Rohan defeated the main power of Sauron in the Morannon theatre on 25 March
column3: causing the northern army to lose hope. Seeing the morale of their foes being sapped by news of victory in the south
column4: the Army of Dale under the new Kings - Bard II and Thorin Stonehelm - managed to lift the siege on 27 March and drove the Easterlings out of Dale.

column1: The battle was incredibly important in the course of the War of the Ring:  if Saurons Easterling armies had beaten the Dwarves and Men of Dale
column2: they would have been able to join up with Saurons forces from Dol Guldur in their attacks on the Woodland Realm of Mirkwood and Lothlórien
column3: tipping the scales in favor of Mordor.  This would have enabled Mordors armies to flank the forces of Gondor and Rohan from the North and rear.  Gandalf himself commented that had the Battle of Dale been lost in this way
column4: the forces of the West would have been crushed regardless of the victory at the Battle of the Pelennor Fields.

column2: while the army of Rohan is mustering at Edoras
column3: Gimli comments to Legolas that he wishes they had a legion of Dwarves to help.  Legolas responds that the Dwarves of Lonely Mountain and Elves of Mirkwood cannot march south to war against Mordor
column4: for he fears that war is already marching upon their own lands.  In the DVD commentary
column5: Peter Jackson explained that this brief exchange was a nod to the Battle of Dale
column6: as well as Saurons attacks on the Woodland Elves and Lothlorien in the northern theatre of the war.  However
column7: Jackson explained that while he wished to show these other battles and that the War of the Ring was a truly global conflict
column8: they simply didnt have the resources or time to construct entirely new sets and film more expansive battle scenes.  Reluctantly Jackson could not show these events
column9: but wanted to somehow acknowledge why the Elves and Dwarves arent coming to aid the besieged Minas Tirith.
